Header.P1: As part of the LMS project, patients contribute their experiences, clinical information, and samples to make data freely available for any LMS researchers. By generating the most comprehensive dataset for LMS, the entire cancer research community can make discoveries that can lead to a better understanding of the disease and changes for future treatments. The project is part of Count Me In, a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research. The project also works in collaboration with a growing coalition of nonprofit advocacy partners.
Header.P2: This project has been built with the guidance and input of many different members of the LMS community. Below we have answered some general questions about this project, as well as questions that are specific to different members of the community - please read any and all that may apply. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to us at info@LMSproject.org or by phone at 651-403-5556.

Footer.P1:
Still have more questions? Feel free to reach out to us at
info@LMSproject.org or by phone at 651-403-5556.

Questions.Question: What is the goal of the LMS project?
Paragraphs: The goal of the LMS project is to transform cancer care by enabling all patients who have ever been diagnosed with leiomyosarcoma to accelerate biomedical research through sharing their cancer samples, clinical information, and their experiences. In order to achieve these goals, datasets containing linked clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient-reported data (without including any personal information) will be regularly shared with the biomedical research community through scientific repositories such as cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics and the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Genomic Data Commons.

Questions.Question: What does participation look like?
Paragraphs: Participants can join through the project website to share their information and experiences with us.

• Provide consent: The consent form is how participants give researchers their permission to take part in the study. It will also allow people to elect to share samples of saliva, blood, and/or tissue, as well as copies of their medical records. This document is several pages, but we encourage participants to take their time and reach out to the project team with any questions.
• Tell us where you’ve been treated: We ask where participants have been treated, so that we can request medical records, and if applicable, archived tumor tissue.

• Respond to surveys: In these surveys we ask questions about a participant’s experience with LMS, like when they were diagnosed and the types of treatments they've had. Participants may also be contacted by the team to participate in focus groups or additional surveys about their experiences participating in the project.

• Provide a saliva and/or blood sample: We will send participants a kit to collect a sample of their saliva and/or blood, along with easy to follow instructions. We will study these samples to help improve our understanding of cancer by comparing the normal DNA in a participant's saliva or blood to their tumor DNA from any tumor samples we may collect.

Questions.Question: Are there any benefits that participants receive for participating?
Paragraphs: While there are no explicit benefits that individuals receive for enrolling in the LMSproject, the project offers some optional opportunities to become more involved that may be of interest to participants looking to learn more about the samples they provide.

• Receive information about what we’ve learned from your tumor sample (optional): If a participant elects to share archive tissue samples with the project, we may be able to share information from the genomic sequencing of the tumor sample back with the participant. This information is intended to highlight how participant sample(s) are contributing to research and will not have implications for their treatment or prognosis. Because of regulatory restrictions, we are unable to share results with participants in New York and Canada.

• Learn more about your normal DNA (optional): The project is also partnering with Invitae in order to sequence and share information on germline DNA (or “normal” DNA) from saliva samples. During the project, participants will be able to decide if they would like to provide an additional saliva sample to learn more about their normal DNA and speak with a genetic counselor to understand these results. If a participant chooses not to participate in this process, their data will not be shared with Invitae. This process is not available for participants in Canada, as Invitae is not licensed to provide genetic counseling services there.

Questions.Question: Who is conducting this research?
Paragraphs: This project is being conducted by the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and Count Me In, a non-profit research initiative that conducts patient-partnered studies of cancer. Count Me In's Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) Project and Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) Project are supported by a grant from the National Cancer Institute's Cancer Moonshot program and are part of the Participant Engagement and Cancer Genome Sequencing (PE-CGS) Network of research centers.

Questions.Question: Who is eligible to participate?
Paragraphs: Anyone who has been diagnosed with leiomyosarcoma (LMS) at any point may participate if they live in the USA or Canada. We welcome people of all ages, genders, races, ethnicities, and abilities.

If you are a parent of a child diagnosed with LMS, you can provide consent for them to participate in the project. Depending on their age, we may also ask them to provide permission to participate through assent.

At this time, we are only able to obtain samples and medical records from patients who live in the United States and Canada, as there are regulatory restrictions that do not allow us to obtain saliva, blood, tumor samples and medical records from international patients.

Questions.Question: Are there any costs for participants to participate?
Paragraphs: No, there are no costs for the participant associated with any step in the project.

Questions.Question: Is this research being conducted for profit?
Paragraphs: No. This project is a not-for-profit research endeavor. Our mission is to generate, aggregate, and freely share data with the research community in order to accelerate discoveries. All data shared with the research community will have readily identifiable information removed.

Questions.Question: How has the LMS community been involved in the design of this project?
Paragraphs: We have worked closely with patients, parents, and patient advocates within the LMS community from the beginning of this project through its design and implementation. The community has been involved in all aspects including concept, goals, messaging, surveys, and the design of this website. The project also partners with leading researchers working in LMS.

We’re proud to have our Advocacy Partners Leiomyosarcoma Support & Direct Research Foundation,National Leiomyosarcoma Foundation, and Sarcoma Sunflower Brigade to partner with and support this project.

Questions.Question: Is this study a clinical trial?
Paragraphs: This study is not a clinical trial. A clinical trial is “a type of research study that tests how well new medical approaches work in people. These studies test new methods of screening, prevention, diagnosis, or treatment of a disease.”

Participation in the LMSproject will not have any impact on the participant’s course of care for leiomyosarcoma. We are not permitted to give any clinical advice as part of participation in this project. The testing we are performing is for research and may not provide information about a participant’s tumor that would lead to changes in their care and treatment plan.

If participants elect to share tumor samples with the project and we are able to successfully sequence sample(s), we will share what we’ve learned from tumor sequencing with participants. When a participant consents to the study, they will be able to choose whether or not to receive this information. An example of what this information could look like can be found here.

In some cases, we may not be able to share what we’ve learned from tumor sequencing with participants. Because of regulatory restrictions, we are unable to share results with participants living in or samples from institutions in New York and Canada. More details on NY state restrictions can be found here.

Questions.Question: What is the difference between tumor and germline DNA?
Paragraphs: Tumors are made of cells in a person's body whose DNA has mutated so they are no longer healthy and normally-functioning. A person’s  germline (also called "normal") DNA is the DNA that is in all the healthy cells in the body. We can compare a person’s tumor DNA to the germline to learn more about the genetic mutations that are present in their cancer. Germline testing looks at the “normal” DNA in a person’s body. This is sometimes done to see if there is a mutation present that may have been inherited

Questions.Question: How is this different from clinical/commercial genomic testing?
Paragraphs: There are many types of genetic testing, also called sequencing. Clinical-grade genetic sequencing is done in a particular type of lab (called a CLIA lab) that has stricter parameters to make sure that the data produced meets certain quality standards. Our genetic sequencing is clinical-grade and done in a CLIA lab, so we are able to share what we’ve learned from participants' tumor samples with them.

There are also different types of genetic sequencing depending on what a researcher or physician is interested in. A panel test might be ordered to look at one or several segments of DNA (called genes) that are already known to have an impact on humans if mutated.

This project performs Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) on tumor samples, meaning that we look at all of the parts of the DNA that are being used by the body to make proteins. For germline sequencing, Invitae will conduct a panel test for specific genes known to be associated with sarcoma, many of these genes are also associated with an increased risk of other cancer types.

Questions.Question: Can these results be shared with a participant’s doctor/clinical team?
Paragraphs: The tumor sequencing is performed in a clinical laboratory and so if a participant chooses to share the results with their doctor, their doctor can place the information in the participant's medical record.
If you or your doctor thinks having your tumor sequenced or profiled will help with your care, then we recommend that standard testing for clinical purposes be ordered by your doctor.

Questions.Question: Who will use participant samples and see participant information?
Paragraphs: Samples and health information for participants will be available to study staff and researchers at Count Me In, the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. More details about how we protect participant information and samples can be found in the consent form.

After removing a participant’s name and other readily identifiable information, we will share results obtained from their participation with the greater research community via established public scientific databases (for example, the National Institute of Health/National Cancer Institute data portals such as the Genomic Data Commons and dbGaP, and the cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics). Some of these databases are publicly viewable by anyone with internet access, and some are restricted to qualified researchers.

If a participant chooses to have germline sequencing done with Invitae, the project will provide Invitae with the participant’s name and contact information. The data and report generated by Invitae will be shared with the participant and with study staff associated with the project. The germline results from Invitae will not be shared in scientific databases.

Sections.Title: My child has been diagnosed with LMS

Questions.Question: What happens when my child with LMS becomes an adult?
Paragraphs: When your child reaches the age where they can consent for themselves, they need to do so to continue to participate in the project. For the US and Canada, this varies by locations and is between ages 18 and 21.

If your child remains in the study when they reach the age where they can consent for themselves, the project team will contact them to re-consent to the study. We will contact you to get your child’s contact information. If your child consents, the project team will continue to request medical records and tissue samples from any point in your child’s treatment.

Sections.Title: My child or someone I know passed away from LMS

Questions.Question: Can I provide access to medical records and tissue on behalf of someone who passed away?
Paragraphs: The LMSproject cannot currently obtain medical records or tissue samples for individuals who have passed away. We are exploring future plans for a next-of-kin process, but this will take time to develop. Through the Loved Ones survey, you may choose to opt-in to be re-contacted by the study if a process is developed to enable this.

Sections.Title: I am a member of the community who would like to get involved

Questions.Question: How can I spread the word about the LMSproject?
Paragraphs: If you would like to learn more about how to spread the word about the project, or if you have any suggestions or questions about the project, please email us at info@LMSproject.org.

Questions.Question: How can I receive updates on the LMSproject?
Paragraphs: If you would like updates on the project, please sign up for our mailing list.

About.Title: About Us
About.TitleText: The Leiomyosarcoma Project is part of Count Me In, a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.
About.countMeInTopText: Count Me In is stewarded by the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Emerson Collective.
About.countMeInMiddleText: Count Me In's Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) Project is supported by a grant from the National Cancer Institute's Cancer Moonshot program and is part of the Participant Engagement and Cancer Genome Sequencing (PE-CGS) Network of research centers.
About.countMeInBottomText: The Leiomyosarcoma Project has been designed and implemented collaboratively with leiomyosarcoma patients, advocates, caregivers, loved ones, cancer researchers, and clinicians.
About.AdvisoryProjectSummary: The Leiomyosarcoma Project Advisory Council (PAC) is made up of patients, advocates, caregivers, and loved ones who have been impacted by leiomyosarcoma. The PAC meets regularly with the project operations team via video calls to develop all aspects of the project, including survey questions, the project website, the project name and logo, and sample kits.
About.AdvisorBio10:
Blake Tomkinson, PhD, MBA, currently a pharmaceutical consultant in oncology, has over 25 years of experience in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industry. Blake has extensive research and clinical development experience in virology, immunology and oncology with expertise as a project leader, business development search and evaluation and clinical development design and strategy of small molecules, monoclonal antibodies, and peptide compounds at OSI/Gilead, Sanofi, EMD Serono/Merck KGaA and Kura Oncology.

Blake also recently established the Diana’s Fibroid Foundation (DFF) with his daughters in honor of his wife, Diana Leigh Tomkinson, who passed in Feb 2020 following a four-year battle with uterine PEcoma, a rare sarcoma. The DFF’s mission is to educate women about the potential risk of malignancy, research the underlying causes of fibroid-associated malignancies, and support early detection of malignant cells.

Blake received his PhD in Immunology from the University of Massachusetts Medical School and did his post-doctoral research in molecular biology at Brigham and Women’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School. Blake received his MBA from the University of Colorado, Denver.
About.AdvisorBio6: Cherry Kim is a Marketing Project Manager and lives in Oakland, CA with her teenage son. Her wife of 24 years, Rhonda, passed away in the fall of 2021 after battling stage 4 Uterine Leiomyosarcoma. She was Rhonda’s caretaker, cheerleader and advocate for all things, whether it was medical, insurance or home life needs. Cherry took a year off work and dedicated that time to take Rhonda on daily walks and drives around the Bay Area to bask in nature’s beauty. After seeing the successes as well as long term side effects of the various chemotherapy treatments Rhonda underwent for 2 years, Cherry was motivated to help get the LMS Project get launched to help other individuals have a stronger and longer chance of survival.
About.AdvisorBio11:
Jeff was diagnosed with Leiomyosarcoma in April 2017. The initial tumor was addressed with surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation. In the Fall of 2021 he was diagnosed with a recurrence which was addressed with chemotherapy and major surgery. Jeff is eager to do whatever he can to help researchers figure out how to best help those afflicted with this disease, and perhaps one day cure it. These activities include:
  • captain of Team Sarcoma for the Dolphins Challenge Cancer fundraising event that supports Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center in Miami where he has received most of his care
  • actively supports activities of the National Leiomyosarcoma Foundation
  • contributed live tumor tissue to pattern.org, part of the Rare Cancer Research Foundation
  • contributed paraffin block tumor tissue to the LMS Tissue Bank at Stanford University
  • participates in the MyPart rare tumor study
Jeff’s very excited to participate on this Project Advisory Council for the leiomyosarcoma Count Me In project.
About.AdvisorBio8:
When Mary Anne was a child she contracted Polio during the last epidemic before the vaccine. She learned about advocacy by her parents who got her the best medical care at Boston Children’s Hospital. Thankfully she survived.

This cancer diagnosis shocked her, but she knew she had to educate herself about this Leiomyosarcoma. Her search led her to Dana Farber Cancer Institute where her top notch Medical Team has guided her to understand this rare cancer. ULMS now stage IV with lung and bone metastasis has taught her to maneuver the battle of a lifetime.

Early on in 2014-2015 she founded the Sarcoma Sunflower Brigade, a Facebook Support Group with four members. Now with over 2300 members the group is Stronger and Dedicated to support and knowledge sharing. Mary Anne knows Knowledge is Power! She shares a tool kit of survival skills and options like using cognitive abilities to cope, reminding ourselves to stay grounded and be grateful.

It’s hard to believe that she just recently survived a bout with covid making this her second epidemic in my 73 years! It’s more important to stay connected during this troublesome lonely time. Her two amazing sons and five precious grandchildren are her world. She stays in treatment and believes that through her resilience she is surviving and able to share hope. We are Stronger Together.
About.AdvisorBio4: Matthew Haist was diagnosed with LMS in April 2019. After a major resection of his collarbone and removal of other infected areas he had clear margins. 3 months later he had mets in my lungs. I have been doing chemo and radiation ever since. Last nodule was radiated june 2021 No evidence of new disease.
About.AdvisorBio1: Mitch is a recently retired diagnostic radiologist living in Denver.  He is a survivor of Leiomyosarcoma, diagnosed in 2011.  Since 2012 he has been an active patient advocate for all sarcomas, but especially leiomyosarcoma.  Since 2013 he has been on the Board of Directors of the National Leiomyosarcoma Foundation that is committed to patient education and support and the funding of Leiomyosarcoma specific research.  With his wife Annie in 2018, he helped to establish the NLMSF-SPAEN International LMS Research Roundtable composed of basic science sarcoma researchers, research medical and surgical sarcomas oncologists from Canada, Europe, Japan and the United States whose mission is to do research to better understand the basic science of LMS with the aim of developing novel more effective treatments for this rare cancer.  Currently, there are 120 Roundtable members.  Mitch is a member of several cancer and sarcoma organizations including the American Society of Clinical Oncology), the American Association of Cancer Research, the Connective Tissue Oncology Society, and the European Society for Medical Oncology and is a patient advocate for the ECOG-ACRIN Cancer Research Group and its Sarcoma Working Group. He has also been an active participant in the SARC Research Advocacy Council and the Sarcoma Coalition.
About.AdvisorBio2: Stacey Simpson Duke is a pastor, a writer, a mom of twin teenage boys, and a research advocate on the SARC Research Advocacy Council. She has been living with stage 4 leiomyosarcoma for five years. Since her diagnosis, she has been on an odyssey of self-education, becoming a voracious reader of medical research, a ferocious self-advocate, and a passionate, vocal proponent of patient empowerment. She believes that patient-researcher collaboration is key to accelerating rare cancer research and improving patient experiences and outcomes. She has found support, education, and hope through her participation in online communities and conversations, especially as a member of Leiomyosarcoma Support & Direct Research Foundation (LMSDR), and also as a learner in conversation on social media with doctors, researchers, and advanced cancer patients. Stacey is the daughter of a father who lived just 11 weeks beyond a diagnosis of angiosarcoma of the small bowel and a mother who lived 19 years beyond a stage 4 melanoma diagnosis. As such, she has witnessed the devastating limits of current medical knowledge–and the possibilities that exist beyond those limits. She is counting on the power of patient-physician-researcher partnership to propel us towards a hopeful future.

About.LearnMoreHeadline: Learn more about the Leiomyosarcoma Project

FYP.Purpose: The purpose of this page is to provide details about the Leiomyosarcoma Project to your physician and care team so they can learn more about the project. You can show them this website, or print out a PDF below with the same information to discuss at your next appointment
FYP.downloadTitle: Download printable PDF to share with your care team
FYP.paragraphTextPart1:
is part of Count Me In, a nonprofit organization
that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer
research. Count Me In is stewarded by the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading
nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer
hospital; and Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization. Count Me In's
Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) Project is supported by a grant from the National Cancer Institute's
Cancer Moonshot program and is part of the
FYP.paragraphTextPart2:
Participant Engagement and Cancer Genome
Sequencing (PE-CGS) Network
FYP.paragraphTextPart3:
of research centers. By partnering directly with patients, we can
accelerate discoveries in Leiomyosarcoma, leading to the development of new therapies and
treatment strategies.
FYP.paragraphTitle2: What is the goal of the Leiomyosarcoma project?
FYP.paragraphText2: The goal of the LMSproject is to transform cancer care by enabling all patients who have ever been diagnosed with LMSeosarcoma to accelerate biomedical research through sharing their cancer samples, clinical information, and their experiences. In order to achieve these goals, datasets containing linked clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient-reported data (without including any personal information) will be regularly shared with the biomedical research community through scientific repositories such as cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics and the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Genomic Data Commons.
FYP.paragraphTitle3: What steps are involved for participants?
FYP.paragraphText3: Participants register for the study online at LMSproject.org. By consenting to the study, patients allow us to request and obtain copies of their medical records, archived tumor samples (if available), and a saliva and optional blood sample. If desired, the participant may also opt-in to providing an additional saliva sample to learn more about their germline (or “normal”) DNA, described in further detail later on this page.
FYP.paragraphTitle4: What steps are involved for the physician’s offices of enrolled participants?
FYP.paragraphText4: When they enroll, participants provide information about where they have received care for their leiomyosarcoma. The study team works directly with medical record and pathology departments to obtain copies of medical records and portions of archived tumor samples. We will ask pathology departments to share only a part of tumor tissue, and not to share anything with us that might be needed for clinical care.
FYP.paragraphTitle5: Do participants receive individual results back from this study?
FYP.paragraphText5:
If a participant elects to
share archive tissue samples with the project, we may be able to share information about what
we learned from the genomic sequencing of the tumor sample back with the participant. This
information is intended to highlight how participant sample(s) are contributing to research and
will not have implications for their treatment or prognosis. Because of regulatory restrictions, we
are unable to share results with participants in New York and Canada.
FYP.paragraphText5part2:
The project is also partnering with Invitae in order to sequence and share information on
germline DNA (or “normal” DNA) from saliva samples. During the project, participants will be
able to decide if they would like to provide an additional saliva sample to learn more about their
normal DNA and speak with a genetic counselor to understand these results. If a participant
chooses not to participate in this process, their data will not be shared with Invitae. This process
is not available for participants in Canada, as Invitae is not licensed to provide genetic
counseling services there.
FYP.paragraphTitle6: What makes this project different from existing studies?
FYP.paragraphText6:
The Leiomyosarcoma Project seeks to empower patients and families to accelerate cancer
research by sharing their samples, clinical information, and experiences with the research
community. Most patients are cared for in community settings where genomic studies are not
typically conducted, so this study connects leiomyosarcoma patients around the country with
genomics research performed at the Broad Institute, allowing them to participate regardless of
where they live. The study was designed in partnership with leiomyosarcoma patients, families,
advocates, and advocacy groups, who continue to provide input on future directions.
FYP.paragraphTitle7: How is the genomic and clinical data shared with the research community?
FYP.paragraphText7:
Next generation sequencing (whole exome and transcriptome sequencing) is performed on
tumor and germline DNA. Sequencing data are linked to de-identified clinical information, and
the resulting data are used to identify drivers of tumorigenesis, mechanisms of response and
resistance to therapies, and diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic biomarkers. The database
of clinically annotated genomic information is shared on publicly available platforms such as
cBioPortal and the NIH.
FYP.paragraphTitle8: What kinds of questions is this project aiming to address?
FYP.paragraphText8:
Over the past decade, genomic characterization of tumors has shed enormous light on the
molecular underpinnings of cancer. These discoveries have led to the development of novel
therapies and preventive measures that have already revolutionized cancer care. Despite this
progress, the genomics of leiomyosarcoma remains poorly understood.
FYP.paragraphText8part2: The types of questions we strive to answer include:
FYP.paragraphText8list1: What are all the genes and mutations that can lead to leiomyosarcoma?
FYP.paragraphText8list2:
What explains why some patients show extraordinary responses to a particular
treatment?
FYP.paragraphText8list3: What explains why some tumors never respond to a particular treatment?
FYP.paragraphText8list4: How can we develop better treatments for leiomyosarcoma?
FYP.paragraphText8part3:
Despite the progress that has been made to begin to answer these questions, we remain far
from the goal. To get there, the detailed genomic characterization of many thousands of
clinically annotated cancer samples will be required.
FYP.paragraphText8part4: If you have any questions about this study, please reach out to us at
FYP.paragraphText8part6: The Leiomyosarcoma project is part of Count Me In.

AllowList.Title: You can choose to allow the study team to:
AllowList.Option1: send you a simple kit to collect a saliva sample
AllowList.Option2: request copies of your medical records

Opt-inToList.Title: You may also opt-in to:
Opt-inToList.Option2: allowing the team to request a portion of tumor tissue (if available)
Opt-inToList.Option3: receiving information about what we've learned from the genomic sequencing of your / your child's tumor sample (if we are able to send these to you)
Opt-inToList.Option4: providing an additional saliva sample to learn more about your/your child's normal DNA with the help of a genetic counselor

ClosingText.Part2: — with your permission, we’ll obtain copies of your medical records and send you a saliva kit.

Steps.Title: STEP 1
Steps.Description: Provide consent and tell us where you’ve been treated
Steps.ImageAlt: Computer screen displaying online consent form

Steps.Title: STEP 4
Steps.Description: Learn with us along the way
Steps.ImageAlt: Speech bubbles sharing hearts and data visualizations

StayInformedSection.Title: Stay informed
StayInformedSection.Text: Sign up for our mailing list or follow us on social media

CountMeInSection.Title: Join the movement and say Count Me In
CountMeInSection.Text: With your help, patients can be the driving force behind transformative cancer research.

Steps.Title: Provide consent for the study
Steps.Text: The consent form is how participants give researchers their permission to take part in the study. This section consists of several pages, we encourage participants to take their time. Any progress will be automatically saved and can be re-accessed later. For participants who are signing up for / with their child, depending on their age, we may also ask the child to “assent” or agree that they would also like to participate in the study.
Steps.ImageAlt: Computer screen displaying online consent form

Steps.Title: Tell us where you’ve been treated
Steps.Text: We ask where patients have been treated for their cancer, so that we can request medical records, and if applicable, archived tumor tissue.

Steps.Title: Respond to surveys about you and your experience with cancer
Steps.Text: In these surveys we ask questions about a participant’s experience with leiomyosarcoma, like when they were diagnosed and the types of treatments they've had.

Steps.Title: Provide a saliva and/or blood sample
Steps.Text: We will send participants a kit to collect a sample of their saliva and/or blood, along with easy to follow instructions. We will study these samples to help improve our understanding of cancer by comparing the normal DNA in a participant's saliva or blood to their tumor DNA from any tumor samples we may collect.

Participations.Text: Over time, we will provide participants with regular updates about the status of the research and share any discoveries that they have enabled us to make. We may also contact participants to participate in focus groups or provide additional feedback related to the overall project experience — we want to hear what’s important to you.
Participations.ImageAlt: Speech bubbles sharing hearts and data visualizations

Participations.step: Receive information about what we've learned from your tumor sample, if you choose
Participations.Text: If participants choose to share archive tissue samples with the project, we may be able to share information about what we've learned from the genomic sequencing of a participant's tumor sample back with them. This information is intended to highlight how participants are contributing to research and will not have implications for their treatment or prognosis. Because of regulatory restrictions, we are unable to share results with participants in New York and Canada.
Participations.Button: What types of information is shared about tumor samples?
Participations.Button1: Download printable PDF to share with your care team

Participations.step: Learn more about your normal DNA, if you choose
Participations.Text: The OSproject is also partnering with Invitae in order to sequence and share information on germline DNA (or “normal” DNA) from saliva samples. During the project, participants will be able to decide if they’d like to provide an additional saliva sample to learn more about their/their child’s normal DNA and speak with a genetic counselor to understand these results. If a participant chooses not to participate in this process, their data will not be shared with Invitae. This process is not available for participants in Canada, as Invitae is not licensed to provide genetic counseling services there.
